title: How to Improve Remote Control Effectiveness

steps.title: An IF receiver (RX) is an optical sensor that detects a signal from the IR transmitter (TX) on your remote.
steps.content: An IF receiver (RX) is an optical sensor that detects a signal from the IR transmitter (TX) on your remote. Look for the receiver on the front face of the TV or device. Most often, the IR receiver is discretely placed along the top or bottom edge of the screen and covered by a red or gray film or plastic lens. Use a flashlight to better locate the receiver lenses. Sometimes they are so small and placed within the protective edge of LCD screens or the covers color match and are flushed in with the surface.

steps.title: Check for a damaged vent or infrared light bulb.
steps.content: Check for a damaged vent or infrared light bulb. A damaged or scratched transmitter diode may not effectively send out signals to your device.

steps.title: Polish scratched or dull Infrared diode lenses on old beat up remotes.
steps.content: Polish scratched or dull Infrared diode lenses on old beat up remotes. Remove any buildup grime or dirt from old remote controls.

steps.title: The IR/RX surface lenses should stay clean and dust free.
steps.content: The IR/RX surface lenses should stay clean and dust free. A dirty IR can diminish effective controller distance by several feet.

steps.title: If the receiver is located at the bottom of the screen, raising the TV will help.
steps.content: If the receiver is located at the bottom of the screen, raising the TV will help. Having the unit too far back from the edge may obstruct the line of sight between the remote controller and the receiver.

steps.title: Many devices like STBs have dark covers over the sensors and/or senders.
steps.content: Many devices like STBs have dark covers over the sensors and/or senders. Sometimes you'll see a thin film of color that can be peeled off. Remove the film cover for better results.

steps.title: Try putting an aluminum foil reflector or collector around the sender/sensor.
steps.content: Try putting an aluminum foil reflector or collector around the sender/sensor. This can improve the signal.

steps.title: Replace remote batteries with a fresh set every 3 - 4 months.
steps.content: Replace remote batteries with a fresh set every 3 - 4 months. When batteries weaken, signal can suffer. Never mix different batteries or new with used. Alkaline batteries may be too strong for a remote control even though they are rated with same voltage.

steps.title: Remove the batteries if a remote won't be used for longer than a month.
steps.content: Remove the batteries if a remote won't be used for longer than a month. This can prevent damage and battery degradation.

steps.title: The way you hold the remote control determines its effectiveness.
steps.content: The way you hold the remote control determines its effectiveness. Point the remote directly at the TV or device for best results.
